importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Landmark study (LEAP) published in 2015 established that early peanut introduction reduces allergy risk, leading to a shift in medical guidelines.
National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases issued updated recommendations for early allergen introduction, influencing public health policy.
New study published in Pediatrics evaluates the long-term impact of early peanut exposure guidelines on allergy prevalence over the past decade.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2015 to 2025 marks a decade during which revised guidelines for early peanut introduction were implemented and evaluated for their effect on reducing food allergy rates in the U.S.

keyTakeAways: Early exposure to peanuts (around 4–6 months of age) reduces the likelihood of developing a peanut allergy.
A 43% reduction in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% reduction in overall food allergy prevalence were observed in U.S. children following the change in guidelines.
The study, led by Dr. David Hill at the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, analyzed health data from over 120,000 children across the U.S.

The revised guidelines, supported by the LEAP study and adopted by the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, have prevented approximately 40,000 cases of peanut allergy and 60,000 cases of food allergy in the past decade.
Despite positive findings, experts like Dr. Corinne Keet caution that implementation remains inconsistent due to parental fears and lack of comprehensive data on eating habits.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study published in the journal Pediatrics reveals that the reversal of decades-old advice—stopping babies from eating peanuts—has significantly reduced food allergies in the U.S. Over the past decade, since the 2015 LEAP study demonstrated that early peanut exposure reduces allergy risk, revised guidelines from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the Dietary Guidelines for Americans have promoted early allergen introduction. This shift has led to a 43% drop in peanut allergy prevalence and a 36% drop in overall food allergies among young children, preventing at least 40,000 cases of peanut allergy and 60,000 cases of food allergy. The findings are supported by data from over 120,000 children across the U.S., though experts caution that implementation has been inconsistent due to parental concerns and data limitations, such as reliance on diagnostic codes and lack of information about actual dietary habits.
title: Reversing peanut advice prevented tens of thousands of allergy cases, researchers say
